title: doc: Effective Go: clarify interface naming conventions
body:
by **david@bitinvert.com**: 
Lines 405-407 in doc/effective_go.html:
By convention, one-method interfaces are named by
the method name plus the -er suffix: <code>Reader</code>,
<code>Writer</code>, <code>Formatter</code> etc.

Clarifying that proper English agent nouns are preferred would be helpful.
As it is currently written, it is not clear if the interface for an Act method should be
named Acter (-er suffix) or Actor (correct English agent noun)

I suggest changing the lines to this, though there might be a better way to say it:
By convention, one-method interface names are
nouns denoting the doer of an action. For example,
the <code>Read</code> method implements
the <code>Reader</code> interface, and
the <code>Generate</code> method implements
the <code>Generator</code> interface.
